  2
  3/** @file    vsip/core/refcount.hpp
  4    @author  Jules Bergmann
  5    @date    2005-01-24
  6    @brief   VSIPL++ Library: Reference count base class.
  7
  8    Classes requiring reference counts should derive from Ref_count.
  9
 10    Notes:
 11    [1] Ref_count is templated on the type of the derived class.
 12        This allows it to call the derived class destructor when
 13        the reference count goes to zero (without declaring the
 14	destructor virtual).  However, this means that Ref_count
 15	should only be used when the static_cast is safe.  This
 16	precludes multiple inheritence and more then level of
 17        additional inheritence that overrides the destructor.
 18
 19    [2] Class Ref_count declares count_ as mutable.  This allows the
 20        increment_count() and decrement_count() members to preserve
 21        const-ness.  This is necessary since it is possible to create
 22        a reference to a const blocks (for example, creating a
 23        subview).
 24*/
 25
 26
 27#ifndef VSIP_CORE_REFCOUNT_HPP
 28#define VSIP_CORE_REFCOUNT_HPP
 29
 30/***********************************************************************
 31  Included Files
 32***********************************************************************/
 33
 34#include <vsip/core/counter.hpp>
 35#include <vsip/core/noncopyable.hpp>

 39/***********************************************************************
 40  Declarations

 43namespace vsip
 44{
 45
 46namespace impl
 47{
 48
 49/// Reference counting base class.
 50
 51/// Ref_count has the following behavior:
 52///  - when constructed, reference count starts out at one.
 53///  - when increment_count is called, the reference count is
 54///    incremented.
 55///  - when decrement_count is called, the reference count is
 56///    decremented, and checked against 0.  If the count is
 57///    0, the destructor of the derived class is called.
 58///
 59
 60template <typename DerivedClass>
 61class Ref_count
 62{
 63  // Constructors.
 64public:
 65  Ref_count() VSIP_NOTHROW : count_(1) {}
 66
 67  // Accessors
 68public:
 69  void increment_count() const;
 70  void decrement_count() const;
 71
 72  // Debug interface
 73public:
 74  unsigned impl_debug_count() const { return count_.value(); }
 75
 76  // Hidden Functions.
 77  // Reference-counted objects should not be copied by value, rather a
 78  // new reference should be created (and the count incremented).
 79private:
 80  Ref_count(Ref_count const&);
 81  Ref_count& operator=(Ref_count const&);
 82
 83  // Member Data.
 84private:
 85  mutable Checked_counter count_;
 86};
 87
 88/// Type and valueused as the second argument to a Ref_counted_ptr
 89/// constructor to indicate that it should not increment the object's
 90/// reference count.  This is purely a flag, rather like std::nothrow.
 91enum noincrement_type { noincrement };
 92
 93/// Smart pointer to a reference counted object.
 94
 95/// Ref_counted_ptr must be instantiated with a type that implements the
 96/// above Ref_count interface.  When constructed with an instance of
 97/// that type, you may specify whether or not the refcount of that
 98/// object should be incremented.  Copy-initialization and assignment
 99/// always increment the reference count of the now-pointed-to object,
100/// and decrement that of the no-longer-pointed-to object if any.
101/// When destructed, the refcount is always decremented.
102///
103/// Pointer arithmetic is not supported.
104///
105/// In all other regards Ref_counted_ptr<T> behaves as T*.
106
107template <typename Obj>
108class Ref_counted_ptr
109{
110  Obj* ptr_;  ///< Underlying pointer.
111
112public:
113  typedef Obj& equiv_type;
114
115  Ref_counted_ptr() : ptr_(0) {}
116
117  /// Basic constructor from an object.  This takes a pointer to the object
118  /// so that you write "Ref_counted_ptr<T> ptr(&obj)" just like an ordinary
119  /// pointer.
120  explicit
121  Ref_counted_ptr(Obj *p) : ptr_(p) { ptr_->increment_count(); }
122
123  /// Variant constructor which does not increment the reference count.
124  /// This is useful when the object has just been constructed, so it
125  /// already has a reference count of 1, and this is the sole handle.
126  Ref_counted_ptr(Obj *p, noincrement_type) VSIP_NOTHROW : ptr_(p) {}
127
128  /// Copy-constructor, always increments the reference count.
129  Ref_counted_ptr(Ref_counted_ptr const& p) : ptr_(p.ptr_)
130  { if (ptr_) ptr_->increment_count(); }
131
132  /// Destructor.
133  ~Ref_counted_ptr() { if (ptr_) ptr_->decrement_count(); }
134
135  /// operator= always increments the reference count of the new object
136  /// and decrements the reference count of the old object.
137  Ref_counted_ptr&
138  operator=(Ref_counted_ptr const& from)
139    {
140      if (ptr_ != from.ptr_)
141      {
142        if (ptr_) ptr_->decrement_count();
143        ptr_ = from.ptr_;
144        ptr_->increment_count();
145      }
146      return *this;
147    }
148
149  void reset(Obj *p, bool increment = false)
150  {
151    if (ptr_) ptr_->decrement_count();
152    ptr_ = p;
153    // If increment was given, p is assumed to be non-zero
154    assert(ptr_ || !increment);
155    if (increment) ptr_->increment_count();
156  }
157
158  /// Dereference operator.
159  Obj&
160  operator*() const VSIP_NOTHROW
161    { return *ptr_; }
162
163  /// Arrow operator.
164  Obj*
165  operator->() const VSIP_NOTHROW
166    { return ptr_; }
167
168  /// An accessor for situations where you need a raw pointer.
169  Obj*
170  get() const VSIP_NOTHROW
171    { return ptr_; }
172};
173
174
175
176/// Smart pointer to a reference counted object, using policy for 
177/// increment and decrement.
178
179/// RPPtr must be instantiated with a type that implements a Ref_count
180/// interface accessed via a Ref_count policy RP.  When constructed
181/// with an instance of that type, you may specify whether or not the
182/// refcount of that object should be incremented.
183/// Copy-initialization and assignment always increment the reference
184/// count of the now-pointed-to object, and decrement that of the
185/// no-longer-pointed-to object if any.  When destructed, the refcount
186/// is always decremented.
187///
188/// Pointer arithmetic is not supported.
189///
190/// In all other regards RPPtr<T> behaves as T*.
191
192template <typename Obj,
193	  typename RP>
194class RPPtr
195{
196  Obj* ptr_;  ///< Underlying pointer.
197
198public:
199  /// Basic constructor from an object.  This takes a pointer to the object
200  /// so that you write "RPPtr<T> ptr(&obj)" just like an ordinary
201  /// pointer.
202  explicit
203  RPPtr(Obj *p) : ptr_(p)
204    { RP::inc(ptr_); }
205
206  /// Variant constructor which does not increment the reference count.
207  /// This is useful when the object has just been constructed, so it
208  /// already has a reference count of 1, and this is the sole handle.
209  RPPtr(Obj *p, noincrement_type) VSIP_NOTHROW : ptr_(p) {}
210
211  /// Copy-constructor, always increments the reference count.
212  RPPtr(RPPtr const& p) : ptr_(p.ptr_)
213    { RP::inc(ptr_); }
214
215  /// Destructor.
216  ~RPPtr() { RP::dec(ptr_); }
217
218  /// operator= always increments the reference count of the new object
219  /// and decrements the reference count of the old object.
220  RPPtr&
221  operator=(RPPtr const& from)
222    {
223      RP::dec(ptr_);
224      ptr_ = from.ptr_;
225      RP::inc(ptr_);
226      return *this;
227    }
228
229  /// Dereference operator.
230  Obj&
231  operator*() const VSIP_NOTHROW
232    { return *ptr_; }
233
234  /// Arrow operator.
235  Obj*
236  operator->() const VSIP_NOTHROW
237    { return ptr_; }
238
239  /// An accessor for situations where you need a raw pointer.
240  Obj*
241  get() const VSIP_NOTHROW
242    { return ptr_; }
243};
244
245/// Store a mutable object.
246
247// Mutable hosts an object by value, but uses a mutable data member,
248// unless the object is const, since const objects cannot be mutable.
249
250template <typename Obj>
251class Mutable
252{
253public:
254  // Constructor.
255  Mutable(Obj& data) : data_(data) {}
256 
257  Obj& get() const { return data_; }
258
259private:
260  mutable Obj data_;
261};
262
263template <typename Obj>
264class Mutable<const Obj>
265{
266public:
267  // Constructor.
268  Mutable(const Obj& data) : data_(data) {}
269
270  // Return a reference to the object.
271  const Obj& get() const { return data_; }
272 
273private:
274  const Obj data_;
275};
276
277/// Store object by value
278
279/// Stored_value holds an object by-value, but presents an interface
280/// similar to Ref_counted_ptr.  This allows views to use Stored_value
281/// and Ref_counted_ptr interchangably.
282///
283/// Stored_value does not call increment_count and decrement_count on
284/// stored value.
285///
286/// Note 050321: Making Stored_value Non_assignable and using default
287/// copy-constructor would work fine.  However, views do not use the
288/// copy-constructor directly, instead they construct a copy by
289/// dereferencing the original Stored_value and using the "Obj*"
290/// constructor.  Making Stored_value Non_copyable emphasizes this usage.
291
292template <typename Obj>
293class Stored_value : public Non_copyable
294{
295  // Constructors and destructor.
296public:
297  typedef Obj equiv_type;
298
299  /// Basic constructor from an object.  This takes a pointer to the object
300  /// so that you write "Stored_value<T> ptr(&obj)" just like Ref_counted_ptr.
301  explicit
302  Stored_value(Obj *p) : data_(*p) {}
303
304  /// Variant constructor to maintain interface compatibility with
305  /// Ref_counted_ptr.
306  Stored_value(Obj *p, noincrement_type) : data_(*p) {}
307
308  ~Stored_value() {}
309
310
311  // Accessors.
312public:
313  Obj& operator*() const VSIP_NOTHROW { return data_.get(); }
314  Obj* operator->() const VSIP_NOTHROW { return get(); }
315  Obj* get() const VSIP_NOTHROW { return &data_.get(); }
316
317  // Member data.
318private:
319  Mutable<Obj> data_; ///< Underlying stored value.
320};
321
322/***********************************************************************
323  Definitions
324***********************************************************************/
325
326/// Increment reference count.
327template <typename DerivedClass>
328inline void
329Ref_count<DerivedClass>::increment_count() const
330{
331  ++count_;
332}
333
334
335
336/// Decrement reference count and delete if it goes to zero.
337template <typename DerivedClass>
338inline void
339Ref_count<DerivedClass>::decrement_count() const
340{
341  // Since this function is const, it is first necessary to
342  // const_cast away const-ness, then static_cast to the derived
343  // type.
344  if (--count_ == 0)
345    delete static_cast<DerivedClass*>(const_cast<Ref_count*>(this));
346}
347
348
349
350/// Pass view through, while decrement reference count of a view's block
351/// (Useful for subview creation).
352
353template <typename View>
354View
355decrement_block_count(
356  View view)
357{
358  view.block().decrement_count();
359  return view;
360}
